Issues.Title: fix(router): Allow question marks in query param values
Issues.Body:
According to the URI spec, question mark characters are valid in query data, so these should accepted by the param parsing.

Fixes #31116

## PR Checklist

- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)

Don't think this needs to be mentioned in docs?

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

Issue Number: #31116

Question mark characters were not accepted as part of a query parameter value, despite them being valid according to the URI spec. This was particularly a problem for including a URL (such as a redirect) as a query param.

## What is the new behavior?

The query param value regex has been relaxed to allow question marks. I have left the query param key regex unchanged, as there seems to be less reason for having question marks as part of a query param key, and this might be more likely to cause problems.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [ ] No

I'm not 100% sure. I suppose theoretically there could applications that rely, knowingly or unknowingly, on the previous behaviour. E.g. an app that is loaded with URLs or other question-mark-containing strings as query string params and relies on this behaviour to strip out the "?" and everything after it in order to product strings that are valid for the app's purposes.

Issues.Title: build: use bazel from node modules
Issues.Body:
The goal of https://github.com/angular/components/commit/2ce5ffd56b70c3791331ceedeadc1f1f6daf3924 was to avoid the use of Bazel through the `node_modules`
because it adds unnecessary code overhead, slows down CI and means that
some tools need to be installed multiple times (such as `yarn`). Unfortunately
when building a release with Bazel right now, the bazel workspace status script
depends on the global `node` binary. This means that we need to bring in Node
when running with the `--config=release` flag.. Since that causes inconsistent behavior
and just complicates the setup, we are using Bazel through Yarn for now. Similar to how
we did it for `angular/angular` with https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/8fc4ae51fb66d14f6dc82712a536c3842205fc6d.

We need to revisit this overall approach in the future.. but for now this seems to be the
simplest approach and we don't want too much effort into this yet. Seems like a general

Issues.Title: virtual-scroll: mat-select with virtual scroll loses selection state
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-2rtvdn

This stackblitz demos 2 mat-selects. 

The one on the left is a standard mat-select. This one works fine on every situation (despite the performace issues that may arise when using large dataproviders)

The one on the right is a mat-select using virtual-scroll. This one has several issues. I will just describe one here which I believe it's not been filed yet.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Select an option from the mat-select on the Right. The option is displayed fine once the selector gets closed.

2. Now open again the mat-select on the right. The selector shows nothing (#15902) but we let's continue working.

3. With the "blank" selector opened, scroll down using the mouse wheel. You will see options are displayed again. Scroll to some position where the "selected" value is not longer visible (outside the MatOption instances used by the virtual scroll). Now Press "ESC". 

4. Boom! The selector goes away (expected) but, despite the mat-select has a "value" set, the component shows nothing.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

If we hit "ESC" o "click outside the mat-select", the control should always display the selected value, no matter if it's using default or virtual scroll.


#### Actual Behavior

The selected option is no longer displayed (but it's still set).

Obs:

1) "mat-select" seems to re-calculate its internal "selectionModel" and "empty" states once the selector is closed. It calculates this state using the available MatOptions which, of course, are not the full-set of options when using virtual scroll.

2) I don't know if this is a "virtual-scroll" bug or a "mat-select" bug but, anyway, the combination of both is crashing (somehow).

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.1
- CDK/Material: 8.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 74

Issues.Title: cdkTreeNodePadding level is ignored
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-de5mhj

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a cdk-tree
2. set the value of cdkTreeNodePadding to "0" for the cdk-tree-node

`<cdk-tree-node *cdkTreeNodeDef="let node" cdkTreeNodePadding="0">`
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

cdkTreeNodePadding should honor the level that is passed as its value. When the passed level is '0', the padding for the cdkTreeNode should be set to `0 * indent pixels`. 

This line contains a comparison that causes the issue when the level is set to '0'

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/6a7fc8156e99c9d3e48e18ab7eef80c25a5c87fc/src/cdk/tree/padding.ts#L93

Instead, it should check if `this._level` is explicitly undefined or null.

`const level = (this._level === null || this._level === undefined) || nodeLevel;` 

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The passed level ('0') is ignored and the padding is set to `level * indent pixels`. All values other than '0' work fine.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.1
- CDK/Material: 8.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
